A-iVjMUgfbI2BwHYQ3AzKQ.text: My waitress disappeared after I received my order.  Gave up trying to get a second cup of coffee.  Had to flag down a waiter to ask for check.

6ryAeAYseyXcvdI1NONcPQ.text: It's a long story how we ended up by St Paul's at 10:00 PM so I won't go into it but it worked out well. We were looking for a late night bite when most places were closed and we came across Cafe Rouge. We were greeted by the manager and seated in a cozy corner with a perfect view of St Paul's Cathedral, lit up by spotlights just across the block.I always love a damn good steak frites and upon the server's recommendation, we both ordered the Bavette steak, cooked rare as suggested. The steak had a nice flavor although it was a tad tough. I would have preferred it to be a little more tender but still not bad. We moved on to desert for the Crepe Chocolat Banane. It was a gooey-chocalate frenzy of bananas and chocolate over crepes. It was paired nicely with a cafe latte.The service here was one of the best features. We were checked on frequently by both the server and manager who made sure our meal was pleasant. It was near closing time but we didn't feel like we were being rushed by any means. Overall, Cafe Rouge was a nice finish to our evening on a night when our plans had been abruptly changed. I saw a few other Cafe Rouge's around London so I'd certainly be happy to return again.

-f9IkU1Fo5OT34MbMad0Xg.text: Myself and three colleagues were aiming for GBK next door to this branch of Cafe Rouge, which was closed for refurbishment. Unfortunately for us we dived in out of the rain and ordered various items for lunch.  Well at least it was dry in there (thats the reason for the star). Ghastly, uninspired food with service to match ( note to the chain: you don't HAVE to be an insouciant waiter in a French restaurant). Real end of the pier experience. I'm actually more annoyed with GBK for allowing me to suffer.

fUeskKWH3I-BktvLHFR1_g.text: After climbing to the top of St. Paul's Cathedral, my legs were twitching and we needed somewhere to take in some nutrients, fast.  We asked a couple locals where we could eat around there, and they said that Cafe Rouge was a chain but a decent one.My mother and I split an order of salmon cakes and an order of crab salad.  The salmon cakes were okay, a little bit dry and very uninteresting.  The crab salad was better, served with a tasty dressing and crunchy crostinis.  Both entrees, however, came on beds of old browning lettuce, with the browned pieces tucked underneath as if we wouldn't notice.The service was snail slow, perhaps in homage to a perception of the French as a lazy and languorous people who also happen to eat snails.  The restaurant was grossly understaffed - the space is pretty big, but the only waiter I saw was our own.  At the very least, this waiter seemed nice, if a bit awkward and shy and evasive of eye contact whenever we wanted service.

wJ3zlE4X8JpcATmhEvJXKw.text: Nice location next to St. Paul's Cathedral, but service was extremely slow. The cappuccino was good but the creme brûlée was lacking in texture and nothing exceptional.

kug-D3df0yPd7rgkgMCGbQ.text: This was the very first restaurant I visited in London--a very memorable place. :)I still had my jet lag and was half unconscious, but I remember I liked this place very much. ;) It has very nice atmosphere. I had a salmon salad and it was delish! The service was prompt and pleasant, too.I'll definitely be back here. :)

HBINkWaN1EAGoG3Y9pqE4Q.text: Good, fresh, healthy food.  Pulled Duck Eggs Benedict was a treat.  Cappuccino was hot, pulled duck was a tad over seasoned, but good nonetheless.    Service was fine, comfortable seating, generally nondescript experience, but that's ok with me if the food is good.

AUFVASiRDaePKj4JJHMmTg.text: Not a place where I would return. It might be an established pearl of the Cafe Rouge chain, but didn't leave a very good impression. The decor -delightful, but not unique; cheerful, but spoilt by the tensed faces of international waiters and waitresses. Were they watched or what?! There is the restaurant part of the place and the bar side of it. Though the restaurant tables were empty, me and my friends couldn't be seated (we only wanted some drinks) and had to wait long minutes until some other, generous customers finished their drinks and let us sit down at their table. Then the long wait for our order. I don't mind giving tips but here this thought somehow didn't seem to cross my mind.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Rouge - London, United Kingdom

lKRZmDM2LJWFXWR8ynBRdw.text: I honestly loved it ! It was quaint and cheap and a quick French bite. I mean really, their confit de canard was good for what it was & didn't disappoint at all. Whilst visiting my nana, I went to Cafe Rouge at least 2-3 times a week for lunch or dinner  and although I'm not too fond of chains, I think they're quite good and reasonable for what you get. It was always pleasurable dining here with nana x

F3o6Y2ph2Lw5EpHn8_IgJw.text: I have to say, Cafe Rouge is one of the better chain restaurants in London. If you're looking for a no-fuss, no-frills French meal, head in their direction. I recently accompanied my visiting grandmother to this location for lunch. What a wonderful place to people-watch (as long as you get a seat by the window). Directly across the street from St Paul's Cathedral, you have stunning views of the cathedral. And you can simultaneously laugh at all of the crazy tourist groups.Our meal was delivered QUICK QUICK QUICK and pretty decent. I have the chicken and roquefort salad (hold the roquefort, of course) while the g-ma enjoyed a cured meats platter (salami and prosciutto with pate, bread, and gherkins). Even though it was bustling during the lunch rush, it wasn't too loud or crazy in there, and the waitstaff managed to keep up.Another approval for the Rouge.

g9efSDkG_-IAOZaVxh0srA.text: I really like Cafe Rouge. It's got a cute decor and the thing I like most is that it does the basics very well. This is something I have found that you can't always take for granted, but Cafe Rouge didn't disappoint in any way. The food was tasty, fresh, fairly priced, served quickly and with a smile. The view from this branch is pretty. Nice. See photo.I would recommend it and I will go back. And not just because my favourite colour est rouge.

DNrtbJfOqBJw4DqnY8L28w.text: Yes, it's a chain, but a good one (for French bistro) at that. And for London standards, fairly, if not, decently priced.Well-appointed but casual bistro atmosphere. The view of St. Paul's cathedral can't be beat!They offer a prix-fixe (is that spelled right?) menu for lunch, about £10-$12. Had the pate and bread, followed by a nice pork sausage and the meltiest-in-my-mouth mashed potatoes, with au jus. I think I licked my plates clean. With an espresso, lunch came out to ~£14. Awesome deal!Also on the lunch menu was Beef Bourgoinogne, which the French girl who ordered it at the next table said was absolutely divine.Service was prompt, friendly but not overbearing. Check out Black's outdoor goods store nearby; they sell cute Wellington-type boots for cheap (~£25)!Makes me wish they had Cafe Rouge stateside!

tChLUCpKFDMjyqKVzDBKUw.text: Some of the best French food I've ever had. I know it's a chain. I know it's not even in France. But it was still so good!  We came here for dinner and tried a few appetizers and the Confit de Canard, with tarte tatin for desserts. The duck was delicious, and the plum sauce was actually sweet and the perfect contrast for the savory duck. The tarte tatin just needed a little more ice cream, but it was done just right. I'd had a similar duck in plum sauce at a more expensive place in Zurich and I have to say this was much, much better. The only thing is, service took forever. I know we Americans like to eat and run instead of having a nice, relaxed, European dinner. the problem wasn't that we wanted to go at a different pace, it was that the waiters kept ignoring us no matter what we did to catch their attention - we'd make eye contact, smile, wave, and they would see us, but no one would come over to see what we wanted. The restaurant was clearly half empty, but for some reason nobody wanted to come help us out. When we mentioned it to one of the servers, he was very apologetic and took our order and made sure it came out promptly, but getting the check was a problem all over again. So, -1 star for all the stress.

QQGuycmNalGElZiABHQhrQ.text: Had a quick lunch here.  Chicken breast sandwich and some tea.  Excellent (though how wrong could you go with a chicken breast sandwich ... wait ... don't answer that!).  Friendly quick service.  Stop by if you're in the area.

YdufKujy0ZZ2aqBqjrOpnA.text: Cafe Rouge is located in front of St Paul's ... very close to where i live. I was at home the whole of sunday evening and so went to this "local" french restaurant for dinner.I was pleasantly surprised by the interior of the restaurant. It was brightly lit, colourful, and the walls were decorated with pictures and posters ... of  the kind i associate with a cafe in Paris. This cheered me up a bit :)I ordered the 2 course fixed price menu (~£12). As a starter i asked for the chicken liver parfait. I love this dish and i think i have ordered it in every meal where i have found it on the menu. Having the soft meat on bread with french butter ... sipping some delicious white wine on the side ... i can't get enough of it :)For the main course i ordered a small medium to well done steak. The steak as well as the chips was good. They served it with dilute garlic sauce which i thought was an unusual choice. But i think the server didn't take down my order correctly. The meat i got was more medium-rare than well done. But it was fine. I enjoyed the food.One reason why i am deducting one star is that Cafe Rouge is a stickler for time. They close at 2230 on sundays and they turn away customers even if they arrive only a minute after the time. Thats the reason why it took me so long to dine here ... i have left disappointed twice and i saw others being turned away as i ate this sunday. In my opinion they should be slightly more flexible in this regard.Cafe Rouge seems to be a pretty nice place to get cheap french food (£15 for two courses and a glass of wine). I will almost certainly come back during slow weekends. But for special occasions there are many better places that i can recommend.

d7B-r_SM3i_PUJeCN0a11A.text: Located right across the street from St Paul's Cathedral, this place started to be just a spot for some drinks, but looking at the menu had us moving to the dining room.   The prices seemed reasonable.  I had the grilled salmon salad, beef bourguignon and a waffle, poached pear and ice cream for dessert.  The food was incredible and I only spent 50 pounds.  I also had a beer and two shots of scotch.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Rouge - London, United Kingdom

swvkE61ksydJ267Mi-cHCg.text: Best chicken Biguett, best mussels, best fries, no wonder why there called french!

muDdOI8mrYXzdFcNADqjKA.text: This branch of Cafe Rouge always seems a bit uncertain of its identity: right opposite St Paul's Cathedral, its customers are a mixture of tourists and people meeting after work. The result is that it hasn't got a lot of atmosphere, and feels much more obviously part of a chain than the Greenwich branch. Having said that, you get the usual middle-of-the-road Cafe Rouge food, which is handy when you fancy something quick but not junk-y, and the service is generally very pleasant. All in all, it's an unremarkable but not unpleasant place for a drink or a light meal.

wXppKVcVFFlTVnd3jPKNWg.text: Not a very thrilling gustatory experience. My wife wasn't feeling well so she ordred a bowl of potatoes with nothig on them (and had to return them twice to avoid eating just raw potatos). I ordered four hors douvres for 10.95 pounds and completely misunderstood what I had ordered (a ramekin of very fishy-smelling crab, two different sets of sliced thin sausages, some blue cheese, some red-pepper coulisse and two slices of ham-- all served with some breads and croutons. All were served cold. Actually, there were plenty of things on the menu I could have tried, so I can only complain for making some bad choices. Given the location, however, across from St. Paul's, the place attracts a tourist trade and need not be known for haute cuisine. The service and ameince were great.

rDY-FYWQmNgB2IQw4c0zyA.text: For a central location and a restaurant chain you really could do much worse than this Cafe Rouge. I have been here several times - at various times of the day with different numbers and types of customers and every time the service has been good, the food has been hot and tasty and the staff have been accommodating. For such a central location with capacity to fit in a lot of customers (I'd say at least 80) - it could all so easily go wrong but this is by far one of the best Cafe Rouges I have been to.

gv694LTTtsn0WiCt7xDCuw.text: Nice view of St Paul's cathedral and a great place to get  a snack and a beverage, I got a croissant ...free wifi too.

EUCbglNq_w6MTj9JDCimIA.text: Good atmosphere, average prices for LondonCoq au Vin and Confit de Canard were very good, but the gratin dauphinois coming with the Confit de Canard was a little bit undercook.

HhdqUVWaGNKIs69L96PFnQ.text: I feel sad to give this review. I had an earlier positive experience that brought me a bag on a rainy Saturday night In London. I was craving a burger and when presented with the menu, chose the beef burger. What was delivered to me was an overdone soupçon of beef. I immediately indicated that it would not be acceptable and could they recook the order. The very nice waitress indicated that is the way it comes and would not improve because the burger is not French cooking, and they don't want to cut other menu options with 'burger and fries'. I said why didn't they either take it off the menu or do it well? She indicated they didn't want to im. prove it but felt they needed a burger option on the menu. Huh??

9_LxWMqVGhxAV8PZ65du_Q.text: The service was terrible.  They served a salad missing ingredients and then told us they were out.  About as inattentive wait staff as you can find.

9v1j84iiOYbcpAg8cfR_IA.text: I remembered going to Cafe Rouge in Hampstead and in Greenwich and finding it quite all right. Although this branch right next to St. Paul's obviously has a great view, I didn't find the atmosphere very comfortable. I only wanted something light so I ordered a salad. I was surprised by the neat, colourful presentation but not really convinced by the flavour.This place is probably a convenient solution for tourists but definitely not a place you have to go to.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Rouge - London, United Kingdom

V6uVSfQicFOe9uKYY-uolQ.text: They have the best toasted English muffins...not on the menu, you have to ask forthem with a side of butter and jam....what a treat!

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Rouge - London, United Kingdom. toasted English muffin, side of butter & jam...looking at St. Pauls Cathedral

3CxvjXcPK-BwZUiNPLpvLw.text: I had a glass of champagne with my friend to kill time for a Christmas celebration at St.Paul's cathedral. It was around 5pm and relatively empty but a cafe-seat was limited. So a staff took us to the counter-seat left available for the last two.It was only £4.7or4.9. cheaper than I had expected but I had a good time.After paying, I got a 50% discount ticket for food. I hope I won't lose it.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Rouge - London, United Kingdom

AY3TvimBhnIofE-tkUwrFw.text: Excellent service, friendly staff. Food was ok. The wine was great, so great spot to chat and drink on a Thursday evening, which seemed crowded and loud everywhere else. I was hoping for more from the based on the menu which sounded delicious.

BOux5W19Z4v3aZVrgCztUQ.text: Spending an hour or two waiting for hubby to finish his business meeting I'm in cafe rouge and one waitress in particular is being so sweet, bless her she is singing, dancing, chatting, an asset to her employer.I'm only enjoying a drink, it's lunchtime and busy as could be, but it's great food great value great service as always

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Rouge - London, United Kingdom. The Christmas menu is as great value as the regular menu
Photo of Cafe Rouge - London, United Kingdom. It's busy but friendly
Photo of Cafe Rouge - London, United Kingdom. It's overlooking St. Paul's cathedral

dn-B8-_2Mui-8RhpRlWWGQ.text: After a cold walk around the St. Paul's area my cousin and I were ready for a hot cup of coffee and a tasty treat. Cafe Rouge was just the place to get us both and a break from the cold. Our cappuccinos were served promptly and sprinkled with just the right amount of cocoa, a nice surprise. We both got the pineapple tarte as well and it was the perfect afternoon pick me up. A great place to stop in for a quick bite or just a coffee.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Rouge - London, United Kingdom. Cappuccino with chocolate

8IL_mdN1pNVFFZN0Y9wFzw.text: While taking a walking break from visiting St. Paul's Cathedral, we discovered this cozy little place. It was early, few people here, so no waiting. The staff was lovely and very quick.  The prices are average for London, even on the cheaper side I would say. The afternoon tea was WONDERFUL! You may have tea or coffee and a sweet cake.  We sat by the window and enjoyed the view and people watching. It was one of the most relaxing parts of our trip.

b_mAJH6x0N38aTs7PHAd9Q.text: Was visiting St Paul's Cathedral, & just across from it was this French Cafe gem. They have an afternoon tea set with coffee & a French cake for only £4.5 Lovely restaurant, with open windows, overlooking St. Paul cathedral. Loved the decor! I totally enjoyed sitting at the window table, people watching & having my 'white coffee' & chocolate cake. For that price it's a steal! They were busy even at 4pm...service very good, very French !

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Rouge - London, United Kingdom. The tea set for 4.50! What a deal!
Photo of Cafe Rouge - London, United Kingdom. The decor

wEdreqxgrm2tBoKAEtH2eQ.text: My wife and I travelled to Europe (via London) in 2008 and 2012. We stumbled across this chain, and dined at three of their restaurants on our trips....ABSOLUTELY SUBLIME!. The food, drinks, and service were absolutely top shelf!. All of there food is amazing. Highly recommend this to anyone travelling through the UK. Still waiting for them to open a restaurant here in the states...(lol)

Z_4IeyECEOqyUqfgZdAf2g.text: French, dim lit, jazz, baguette at the door, oh my! Purrfection! Je vous presente Cafe Rouge, mes amis! We had the Lobster bisque, the Plateau a partager ( board of charcuterie, olives, pâté, soft goats' cheese, rocket and a selection of bread with d'Isigny butter) and the holy trinity dessert. Washed down, of course, with wine. Because of all the reasons. The lobster bisque was so dreamy. Like Colin Firth in The Bridget Jones diaries. Sweet, steamy, intense, rich, creamy as fuck, respectful and loves you for who you really are! I didn't think anything could top this, until I had a lusty love affair with the pate. I've never known pate like this, I was living in the dark 'till it came along and showed me what true pate tastes like. It had such complex, complete flavours, 5 dimensions all in one bite! His core, grounded, meaty flavour, the base that then sustains the sweetness, and then the lightness, and then the perfume! Oh, the perfume! And the texture! It was like cutting into cheesecake, creamy, airy, layered! Imagine this: a slice of baguette- crusty outside, soft inside, cut in a big, inviting chunk, drizzle that with melted butter with garlic and herbs, then top with the pate. I got dizzy at one point. For the dessert we had miniature tarte tatin, tarte au citron and fondant aux chocolats. Even though I wasn't blown away by this (not sure I even had the capacity at this point) it was all good. It was the perfect ending to a decadent meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Rouge - London, United Kingdom. A sneak peak: Lobster bisque and Le plateau a partager.

cGyW7A_ZXWmWck2gF7RlAw.text: Fine food and drink, great value, great service, pleasant decor and ambience all added up to create an awesome dining experience for two Americans visiting London. Whodathunkit...Good French cuisine at Olive Garden or Chilis prices! Our waitress Fran was delightful and her menu recommendations were perfect. Anyone used to the routine rudeness of Parisians or the attitude of a typical Manhattan French restaurant maitre'd would be very pleasantly surprised by the charm and warmth of the French hostess who seated us on both our visits. By the way, this is pretty typical of French restaurants in the UK. My wife and I joke that all the most friendly and customer-service oriented people in France get deported to Britain on the Eurostar train from Paris to London.

k7fuykdDr4vnIQclfDtutg.text: Went in on Saturday our first visit to aCafe rouge restaurant and what a pleasantSurprise, I had ribeye steak and askedIf the chef could cook it  blue which he didAnd I can honestly say it was one of theBest pieces of steak I have had in a longWhile and with two starters two mains twoDrinks and one pud for £73 was well worth it.

mvevZpD2uUogy_uBrQ9_RA.text: We arrived for a late evening meal when many other restaurants were just closing. Although we were among the last in the restaurant, you could not tell by the food that was served. Excellent taste and well prepared. The food was wonderful and affordable! Excellent view and service!

ksa5l5tXXWh0axEx8r2puQ.text: Ambience was great but the food only soso. My prefix included pate and mussels.pate was so so and unappetizingly prepared- mussels came out in a small individual pot but some of the buggers tasted a little funky/unfresh. I didn't get sick so maybe it was just the prep? Walk down carter lane - more choices that way.

dOU-DkM4c8jrX3gTgypyFQ.text: The food was amazing so was Allan's service. He French onion soup straight thru to the dessert was a pleasure. I can't believe this listing doesn't have more reviews!!

eLLWfS4PQ20eTUQS8q5j7Q.text: Good food. Kids loved the food from the kids menus. Ate here twice while visiting London.
